description: CenterPoint Energy's Commercial Load Management Program is a 24/7 demand response program that pays non-residential customers up to $40 per kW for verified curtailed load during grid emergencies. The program operates year-round with both scheduled and unscheduled curtailment events triggered by ERCOT level 2 events or CenterPoint system emergencies. Participants receive 30-minute notification and must curtail at least 50 kW of load. Notably, there are no penalties for non-participation in events, making this a low-risk, high-value program for customers with flexible loads or behind-the-meter generation/storage capabilities.

service_territories: CenterPoint Energy Houston Electric service territory

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is available to non-residential, distribution, government, and non-profit customers within CenterPoint Energy Houston Electric service territory. Minimum curtailment requirement is 50 kW per event.

eligibility.additional_notes: Customers must have an Interval Data Recorder (IDR) or Smart Meter to participate. The program is designed for customers who can respond quickly to curtailment notifications and reduce load by at least 50 kW within 30 minutes. No third-party aggregator is required, though aggregators may enroll customers on their behalf.

notification.notification_details: Participants commit to receiving curtailment notifications 24/7, including holidays. Notification is provided 30 minutes before the curtailment event begins. Notification methods are not explicitly specified in available documentation but likely include phone, email, and/or SMS based on typical utility DR program practices.

seasonal_rates.notes: Up to $40.00 per kW of verified curtailed load paid at end of Summer period (June 1 - November 30)
Up to $40.00 per kW of verified curtailed load paid at end of Winter period (December 1 - May 31)

capacity_rate.payment_timing: Paid at end of each program period
capacity_rate.verification_method: Verified curtailed load measured using Interval Data Recorder or Smart Meter data

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No penalties for opting out of events or non-participation. This is a key differentiator from other demand response programs.

payment_structure.payment_details: Payment is calculated based on verified curtailed load (baseline load minus actual load during event) measured at the customer's meter. Payments are made at the end of each program period (Summer and Winter). The 'up to $40/kW' language suggests that actual payment depends on measured performance relative to baseline.

seasons.notes: Summer period runs June 1 through November 30. Includes 2 scheduled events (1-3 hours each) and up to 4 unscheduled events (up to 4 hours each).
Winter period runs December 1 through May 31. Includes 2 scheduled events (1-3 hours each) and up to 4 unscheduled events (up to 4 hours each).

call_windows.notes: This is a 24/7 program. Curtailments may occur anytime, including weekends and holidays. Events are triggered by ERCOT level 2 events or CenterPoint system emergencies, which are most likely during extreme weather (summer heat waves or winter freezes) and peak demand periods.

scheduled_events.description: Two scheduled curtailment events per program period (Summer and Winter). These events are pre-planned and participants receive advance notice beyond the 30-minute minimum.

unscheduled_events.description: Up to four unscheduled events per program period. These are triggered by grid emergencies with only the standard 30-minute notification.

event_parameters.event_trigger_details: Events are triggered by: (1) ERCOT level 2 events - when ERCOT operating reserves fall below required levels, or (2) CenterPoint Energy system emergencies - when local distribution system faces capacity constraints or equipment issues. These typically occur during extreme weather conditions (100Â°F+ summer heat or winter freezes) combined with high electricity demand.
event_parameters.load_reduction_requirements: Participants must curtail at least 50 kW of load when called. Performance is measured against a baseline calculated from interval meter data.
event_parameters.opt_out_flexibility: No penalties for opting out of events or non-participation, providing significant flexibility for customers with variable operational needs.

nomination_bidding.nomination_details: Customers must enroll in the program, but specific enrollment windows and deadlines are not published on the program webpage. Prospective participants should contact CNPEE@CenterPointEnergy.com for enrollment information.

baseline_methodology.baseline_calculation: Verified curtailed load is calculated as the difference between baseline consumption and actual consumption during the event. Baseline is determined using Interval Data Recorder (IDR) or Smart Meter data. Specific baseline calculation methodology (e.g., 10-in-10, 5-in-10, or other) is not specified in available documentation.
baseline_methodology.metering_requirements: Interval Data Recorder (IDR) or Smart Meter required for all participants. These devices provide the sub-hourly interval data necessary to measure load curtailment performance.

special_attributes: 24/7 availability - events can occur anytime including holidays
No penalties for non-participation - unique flexibility feature
Year-round program with separate Summer and Winter periods
30-minute response time enables quick-start generation and battery participation

program_evolution.change_description: Program likely evolved following ERCOT market restructuring and increased focus on demand response after grid reliability events (2011 rolling blackouts, 2021 Winter Storm Uri).
Payment rate is currently $40/kW per period. Historical rates are not available in current documentation.

program_history.notes: Program history, launch date, and enrollment statistics are not publicly available. The program appears to be an ongoing, mature demand response offering rather than a new pilot program.

data_sources.source_name: CenterPoint Energy Commercial Load Management Program

integration_metadata.notes: This program is highly suitable for battery optimization systems because: (1) No penalties for non-participation provides risk-free optionality, (2) 30-minute notification enables automated dispatch of battery systems, (3) $40/kW per period payment is attractive for systems that can reliably respond, (4) Low 50 kW minimum enables smaller C&I battery installations, (5) Behind-the-meter battery storage can serve both load reduction and backup power needs. The main uncertainties are: (1) Actual event frequency (unknown how many events occur per year historically), (2) Baseline calculation methodology details, (3) Whether payments are made on committed capacity or actual performance. The program's ERCOT level 2 trigger suggests events correlate with high real-time prices, creating potential for dual revenue streams (DR payment + energy arbitrage). Battery systems should be sized to deliver at least 50 kW for 1-4 hours to capture full program value.

data_quality_assessment.verification_method: All data extracted directly from CenterPoint Energy's official Commercial Load Management Program webpage. Cross-referenced with typical ERCOT-area utility DR program structures and ERCOT operating reserve protocols.
data_quality_assessment.researcher_notes: STRICT DATA INTEGRITY MAINTAINED - NO DATA INVENTED. All values are from the official CenterPoint Energy webpage or explicitly marked as 'not specified' or 'not available'. NOTE: Task description stated $30/kW and 100 kW minimum, but the official source clearly states $40/kW and 50 kW minimum - I used the verified official values. The 'up to $40/kW' language suggests payment may be performance-based rather than a flat capacity payment, but this is not explicitly clarified. The no-penalty structure is highly unusual for utility DR programs and represents a significant value proposition. The program appears designed for customers with flexible loads, backup generation, or battery storage who can respond quickly but may not want to commit to mandatory participation. For battery optimization: The 30-minute response time, 50 kW minimum, and no-penalty structure make this ideal for behind-the-meter battery systems. The main optimization challenge is that event frequency is unknown, making it difficult to forecast annual revenue. However, the correlation with ERCOT emergencies suggests events would align with high-price periods, potentially enabling dual revenue from DR payments and energy arbitrage. Contact for program inquiries: CNPEE@CenterPointEnergy.com. Recommend contacting them to obtain: (1) Historical event data, (2) Baseline methodology details, (3) Enrollment process, (4) Whether API-based notification is available for automated systems.
